oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A comparison of tildipirosin to tulathromycin as the first treatment for naturally occurring bovine respiratory disease using a 3-day posttreatment moratorium
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hagenmaier, Jacob A.
Terrell, Shane P.
Lukasiewicz, Kip. L.
Thomson, Daniel U.
Bryant, Lonty K.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: bovine respiratory disease
feedlot
tildipirosin
tulathromycin
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Macrolide antibiotics are commonly selected for treatment of bovine respiratory disease (BRD) in conventional feedlot production systems. A randomized complete block design study was used to evaluate the relative efficacy of tildipirosin (TILD) and tulathromycin (TULA) for first treatment of natu­rally occurring cases across 4 commercial feedlots in central Nebraska. A total of 940 beef steers and heifers (668 ± 136 lbs) were enrolled in the study during a 5-month period beginning September of 2019. Cattle diagnosed with BRD and satisfying enrollment criteria were assigned to treatment using a lot-level randomization. Data were analyzed using linear mixed models and generalized linear mixed models. Enrollment body weight, rectal temperature and days-on-feed were simi­lar for cattle regardless of assigned BRD treatment (P ≥ 0.1373). There was no difference in BRD first treatment success (P = 0.9866) or subsequent treatment success (P ≥ 0.6404) between the antibiotics. Case fatality and railer rate also did not differ (P ≥ 0.7924) between TILD and TULA cattle. Carcass data were obtained from the abattoir on a subset of cattle (n = 531), and no characteristics were different between treatments (P ≥ 0.5139). The results of this study suggest similar efficacy of tulathromycin and tildipirosin for first treatment of naturally occurring bovine respiratory disease in commercial cattle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Bovine Practitioner; Vol. 60 No. 1 (2026): ONLINE FIRST; 48-53
